header_summary:
AdamISZ's exploration on adaptor signatures, as detailed in [Reyify](https://reyify.com/blog/adaptors-generalised/), sheds light on their potential to extend beyond current cryptographic practices, especially in enhancing Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKP) and on-chain verification capabilities. This discussion underscores the theoretical and practical implications of integrating adaptor signatures with blockchain protocols to ensure more secure and verifiable transactions. The research presents a nuanced approach towards leveraging adaptor signatures for Discrete Logarithm Equality (DLEQ) verification, illustrating a significant stride in cryptographic methodologies.

The Tokyo summit, as captured in the comprehensive notes shared by [roasbeef](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/ln-summit-2024-notes-summary-commentary/1198), convened Lightning developers to address pivotal enhancements in the Bitcoin and Lightning protocols. Key discussions revolved around the Package Relay, V3 Commitments, and innovations like PTLCs and the Simplified Channel State Machine to bolster privacy, scalability, and transaction efficiency on the Lightning Network. These deliberations highlight the ongoing efforts to refine the network's infrastructure, ensuring it remains robust against evolving technological and operational challenges.

Ariard's contribution to the Bitcoin scripting dialogue, specifically focusing on the `FindAndDelete` function, clarifies its operational nuances and rectifies prevalent misunderstandings within the community. This clarification, detailed at [DelvingBitcoin](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/cve-2024-38365-public-disclosure-btcd-findanddelete-bug/1184/10), emphasizes the intricacies of script execution and the critical role of accurate sighash commitments in maintaining transaction integrity. Such technical insights are vital for developers and researchers dedicated to enhancing the security frameworks of Bitcoin's scripting language.

The bitcoin++ conference discussions, highlighted by 1440000bytes, reveal innovative applications of the ecash protocol, particularly in employing blind signatures for privacy-centric incentives like discount coupons. This novel use-case, further elaborated in [DelvingBitcoin](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/anonymous-discount-coupons-using-chaumian-ecash/1197), exemplifies the expanding utility of cryptographic protocols in fostering secure, private transactions beyond conventional financial contexts. It underscores the growing intersection of cryptography with practical, user-oriented applications, encouraging broader participation and privacy in digital ecosystems.

recent_posts.title: Adaptor generalisation
recent_posts.summary:
- AdamISZ's blog discusses expanding adaptor signatures beyond traditional uses.
- It introduces a two-party protocol for verifying Discrete Logarithm Equality statements.
- The focus shifts from theoretical exploration to practical applications in cryptographic protocols.

recent_posts.title: LN Summit 2024 Notes & Summary/Commentary
recent_posts.summary:
- Over thirty Lightning developers met in Tokyo to discuss advancements in Lightning and Bitcoin protocols.
- Key discussions included Package Relay, V3 Commitments, and improving transaction fee predictability and reliability.
- The summit explored Point Time Locked Contracts, off-chain scalability, and proposed Gossip 2.0 for node efficiency.

recent_posts.title: CVE-2024-38365 public disclosure (btcd `FindAndDelete` bug)
recent_posts.summary:
- `FindAndDelete` modifies a copy for sighash, not the executing script.
- It removes specific stack elements post-`OP_CHECKSIG` execution.
- Nuanced `OP_CODESEPARATOR` behaviors in `SigVersion::Base` were extensively tested.

recent_posts.title: Anonymous discount coupons using chaumian ecash
recent_posts.summary:
- The bitcoin++ conference showcased ecash protocol's use beyond monetary transactions.
- Ecash fosters privacy in incentives through methods like discount coupons.
- This system's technical foundation was demonstrated through proof of concept code.

active_posts.title: Demonstrating Pinning Attacks under Real-World Conditions
active_posts.summary:
- Antoine proposes establishing "free-to-pwn" lightning nodes on the mainnet for attack demonstrations.
- This initiative will enable real-world testing, differing significantly from private or test networks.
- The project aims to expose and discuss the Bitcoin protocol's vulnerabilities realistically and transparently.

active_posts.title: OP_ZKP updates
active_posts.summary:
- The OP_ZKP proposal integrates Zero-Knowledge Proofs in Bitcoin, seeking an efficient ZKP scheme.
- The Inner Product Argument is favored for its minimal assumptions and small proof size.
- Future considerations include the technology's impact on devices and potential alternative schemes.

active_posts.title: Public disclosure of three vulnerabilities affecting Bitcoin Core <v25.0
active_posts.summary:
- Significant security vulnerabilities in Bitcoin Core before version 25.0 were identified.
- A new vulnerability disclosure policy aims to increase transparency and security in the Bitcoin Core community.
- Future vulnerabilities pre-version 26.0 will be disclosed next month, emphasizing ongoing security efforts.

active_posts.title: SuperScalar: Laddered Timeout-Tree-Structured Decker-Wattenhofer Factories
active_posts.summary:
- The SuperScalar mechanism enhances Bitcoin Lightning Network's liquidity without blockchain consensus changes.
- It combines Decker-Wattenhofer strategies, timeout trees, and laddering for scalability and security.
- This system aims to improve liquidity management and adapt to Bitcoin's network dynamics.

active_posts.title: Ecash TIDES using Cashu and Stratum v2
active_posts.summary:
- Integrating BDHKE into Stratum v2 enhances privacy and auditability for pool rewards.
- The process involves miners submitting shares via updated `block_keysets` impacting rewards.
- Proposal aims to improve cryptocurrency mining rewards with references for further exploration.

active_posts.title: Unspendable keys in descriptors
active_posts.summary:
- Taproot integration and hardware signer support enhance Bitcoin Core's wallet development capabilities.
- Generating practical unspendable keys for wallets involves complex properties to ensure security and usability.
- Despite various methods, no perfect solution exists, necessitating further discussion for improved approaches.

today_in_history_posts.title: Out-of-band transaction fees
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Out-of-band transaction fee payments offer privacy benefits but raise consensus concerns.
- A standardized system for these payments could mitigate centralization and ensure fairness.
- Such services necessitate secure, transparent methods for miners to claim bounties.

today_in_history_posts.title: [RFC] Simplified (but less optimal) HTLC Negotiation
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The Lightning Labs team has upgraded the protocol for more simplicity and determinism.
- The updated protocol operates on a half-duplex system, enabling turn-based communication.
- Upon reconnection, two flags, send-in-progress and receive-in-progress, are sent for transaction status.

today_in_history_posts.title: Segwit Ephemeral Anchors
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Ephemeral Anchors introduce key-less outputs for "dusty" values, relying on Bitcoin's legacy script.
- The approach faces challenges with transaction ID malleability and integration with protocols like splicing.
- A proposed solution involves using bip141 and an undefined witness program to add minimal bytes and simplify implementation.
